Posts.Content: Dec 14, 2011 01:41AM AngelaMBlack72 wrote: Well I think we have all been here or someday may be here.  I have been fighting stage IV for almost five years coming up 1/3/12.  I started with mets to bones, hysterectomy found cervix, ovary and pelvic wall, then to skin, then omentum and peritoneal cavity and recently liver and spleen.  I am currently on a trial at Dana Farber with Femara and BMK120 experimental drug, last scan novemeber was stable yet markers are 2,000...they have been up and down.  I have lost weight and had a decrease in appetite due to trial drug.  I went out on saturday and had the most horrible pain in lower back and right leg after being out for three hours xmas shopping, most walking ive done since I have lost the weight.  I have experienced for the first time horrible acid reflux which causes my throat to be achy and sore....every time I eat I say...ugh!  I am now drinking ensure twice a day...just to keep protien going.  So.......coping mechanisms....... I have been very depressed lately....the weight loss and finally for the first time reality of cancer.  Im scared, nervous and wondering what is next?  So, I started dealing with it.  I started acupunture yesterday, it went well.  Today I stayed home from work, to have some time for "me".  I plan to pick up yoga, I think it will help my anxiousness.  I am meditating when I can, rather its five minutes or more.  I have realized things "could be worse" somehow....because somewhere they are worse for someone at this very moment.  I am focusing on my son and the things that make me happy...more so than ever.  If crying helps, its okay.  Make sure you laugh once a day.  Think once a day.  Do something for you once a day, or even once a week, but do that for you.  The main thing to understand is "it is what it is".  We did not choose cancer....but since we do not have a choice pray we have many years left.  I have traveled this past year.  I go to atleast one breast cancer conference a year to learn more.  I think it is important to know all you can about your cancer...so you can fight the beast!  I recently went on ambien to sleep at night because I was getting no sleep, that is part of coping, your rest!  I guess there are many coping mechanisms and there are woman on here that are all in the same or similar situation that will chime in.  I hope I have helped a little.  I try to keep myself very busy so the cancer doesn't take over my mind....although sometimes it does, just as long as it doesn't forever.  I just cut my hours at work but it is the first time since my dx....I realized I need more rest and more time to heal.  I hope you can find ways to cope, I know how hard it is and I wish none of us had to go through cancer....but since we do we have to fight back!  Good luck and feel free to PM me if you need to...Hugs from Maine....

Posts.Content: Feb 24, 2012 03:28PM AngelaMBlack72 wrote: I do not have lobular I have invasive but have the same mets and more...I have bone, skin, peritoneal, omentum, node, spleen, liver. On trial at Dana Farber but may be changing tx due to possible liver growth, also liver is diffused meaning all kinds of tiny lesions same as peritoneal and spleen. Been on all Hormonals now and have done taxol and xeloda. PM with specifics if you want or just post here...it's def a scary road but we are all here...hoping for that one magical drug that stops it...
Posts.Title: Lobular Blues rakulynda penny4cats

Posts.Content: Nov 7, 2011 02:49PM AngelaMBlack72 wrote: I also sent a message to Zoh in her inbox, I was very fortunate to meet this wonderful women at the conference in Baltimore.....even tho it was a quick hug if I do not see her again I will remember that moment.  With that said, here goes my thoughts.  We are all on this board for a reason, most stage IV cancer, for this forum anyway.  Most of us have the same thoughts, struggles, and son on each day forward.  Like most Im sure Zoh has worked just like the rest of us....I personally have worked since I was 13, now 39, single parent at 16.  No matter what opinions we get or how people feel about each situation, the bottom line is we all or most of us have a terminal illness, although everyone is terminal, the difference with us metsters is we may have a very painful ending of our lives and know how its going to happen.  Us women are in this together, we want the same thing, we want to live.  We want to see our children grow up, we want to have a wonderful life to travel or what ever it is we long for.  Sometimes the craziest ideas may make those things come true, or not.  I have mets to my bones, skin, peritoneal cavity, omentum, liver and spleen.....now thats alot of mets.  I am still working full time....DO NOT ASK ME WHY!  Insurance is a good answer....but to be honest with you I feel it keeps me going and it keeps me alive....so that is why I do.  I guess my whole point to this conversation is....we all have thoughts and we all are different.  I look forward to all posts, Zoh's too.  Not all of us are at Zoh's place, her and I have similar paths...we connected and Im glad.  We all need each other.  Lets be honest.  Life is short.  I say, do what you want to do if you can do it.  In the end its your own decision.  I think all of us have been robbed of a full life and for what reason?  We all have families and lots of children who have to live without us someday.  No it is not fair.  What we can do together is stick together.  Welcome all the comments here, just when you think it may offend another maybe PM them.  My thoughts to Zoh were DO WHAT YOU WANT.  There I said it~  One thing I always remembered from a friend of mine who passed last year...she said do what you want while you feel good because someday you probably will not with stage IV cancer, she is right.  So, take this time to hug one another, love each other and feel free to be open here because we are all in this together and I am so glad that I keep meeting the strongest women I have and will ever meet in the world.  I hope this all made sense, and again I am so glad I got to meet Zoh....
